description: Which of the following best defines a graph?
options: A collection of nodes connected by edges
A hierarchical structure with parent-child relationships
A linear sequence of elements
A set of unrelated data points

description: What are the two primary components of a graph?
options: Nodes and queues
Nodes and edges
Edges and stacks
Vertices and arrays

description: Order the conceptual steps to represent a graph in a conceptual model.
options: Define the set of nodes (vertices)
Determine the relationships (edges) between nodes
Decide if the graph is directed or undirected
Assign weights if applicable

description: Match each graph term with its correct definition.

matches.Vertex: An individual node in a graph
matches.Path: A sequence of edges connecting vertices

description: Which of the following is NOT a typical characteristic of graphs?
options: Nodes and edges
Cyclicity
Linear ordering
Connectivity

description: What distinguishes a directed graph from an undirected graph?
options: Directed graphs have weighted edges only
Directed graphs have edges with a specified direction
Undirected graphs have no nodes
Undirected graphs allow multiple edges between nodes

description: Order the conceptual process for analyzing connections in a graph.
options: Identify all vertices
Examine each edge to determine connections
Determine connectivity or components
Analyze potential cycles or paths

description: Match each graph property with its description.

matches.Undirected: Edges lack direction and are bidirectional

description: Which application commonly uses graphs for modeling?
options: Linear data processing
Network routing and social networks
Simple arithmetic operations
Sequential file storage

description: Which property is essential for a graph to be considered connected?
options: Every vertex has at least one edge
There exists a path between every pair of vertices
The graph is undirected
The graph is acyclic

description: Which of the following best defines an adjacency list representation of a graph?
options: A 2D array representing connections between nodes
A collection where each node stores a list of its adjacent nodes
A matrix that stores all pairs of node connections
A sequential list of nodes without edge information

description: What is a key advantage of using an adjacency list over an adjacency matrix?
options: It requires more memory
It allows faster access for dense graphs
It efficiently represents sparse graphs with fewer edges
It simplifies the representation of complete graphs

description: Order the conceptual steps to construct an adjacency list for a graph.
options: List all vertices
For each vertex, initialize an empty list
For each edge, add the destination vertex to the source vertex's list
Include the reverse edge for undirected graphs if needed

description: Match each term related to adjacency lists with its description.

matches.Neighbor: An adjacent vertex connected by an edge
matches.List: A collection of adjacent vertices for a given node

description: Which scenario is best suited for using an adjacency list representation?
options: Graphs with a very high density of edges
Graphs with very few vertices
Sparse graphs with relatively few edges compared to vertices
Graphs where edge lookup speed is not important

description: What information is typically stored in each entry of an adjacency list?
options: Only the vertex identifier
The vertex identifier and a pointer to the next adjacent vertex
The weight of the edge exclusively
The vertex identifier along with its adjacent vertices and optionally edge weights

description: Arrange the conceptual process for adding an edge in an adjacency list representation.
options: Identify the source vertex
Locate its list of adjacent vertices
Append the destination vertex (and weight if applicable) to the list
Repeat for directed or undirected edge as required

description: Match the advantages of an adjacency list with the reasons they apply.

matches.Space Efficiency: Uses memory proportional to the number of edges

description: Which property does an adjacency list naturally exhibit when representing sparse graphs?
options: High memory consumption
Inefficient edge lookup
Efficient use of space
Redundant edge information

description: What is a potential disadvantage of using an adjacency list representation?
options: It provides constant-time edge lookups for dense graphs
It can require extra time to check if a specific edge exists
It uses more space than an adjacency matrix in all cases
It does not support weighted graphs
